column2: Shaston, the ancient British Palladour,

column2: From whose foundation first such strange reports arise,

column2: (as Drayton sang it), was, and is, in itself the city of a dream. Vague imaginings of its castle, its three mints, its magnificent apsidal abbey, the chief glory of South Wessex, its twelve churches, its shrines, chantries, hospitals, its gabled freestone mansions--all now ruthlessly swept away--throw the visitor, even against his will, into a pensive melancholy, which the stimulating atmosphere and limitless landscape around him can scarcely dispel.
column3: (as Drayton sang it), was, and is, in itself the city of a dream. column2: The spot was the burial-place of a king and a queen, of abbots and abbesses, saints and bishops, knights and squires.
column3: The spot was the burial place of a king and a queen, of abbots and abbesses, saints and bishops, knights and squires.

column2: The bones of King Edward "the Martyr," carefully removed hither for holy preservation, brought Shaston a renown which made it the resort of pilgrims from every part of Europe, and enabled it to maintain a reputation extending far beyond English shores.
column3: The bones of King Edward "the Martyr," carefully removed hither for holy preservation, brought Shaston a renown which made it the resort of pilgrims from every part of Europe, and enabled it to maintain a reputation extending far beyond English shores.

column2: To this fair creation of the great Middle-Age the Dissolution was, as historians tell us, the death-knell.
column3: To this fair creation of the great Middle Age the Dissolution was, as historians tell us, the death knell.

column2: With the destruction of the enormous abbey the whole place collapsed in a general ruin: the Martyr's bones met with the fate of the sacred pile that held them, and not a stone is now left to tell where they lie.
column3: With the destruction of the enormous abbey the whole place collapsed in a general ruin: the Martyr's bones met with the fate of the sacred pile that held them, and not a stone is now left to tell where they lie.

column2: The natural picturesqueness and singularity of the town still remain; but strange to say these qualities, which were noted by many writers in ages when scenic beauty is said to have been unappreciated, are passed over in this, and one of the queerest and quaintest spots in England stands virtually unvisited to-day.
column3: The natural picturesqueness and singularity of the town still remain; but strange to say these qualities, which were noted by many writers in ages when scenic beauty is said to have been unappreciated, are passed over in this, and one of the queerest and quaintest spots in England stands virtually unvisited to day.

column2: It has a unique position on the summit of a steep and imposing scarp, rising on the north, south, and west sides of the borough out of the deep alluvial Vale of Blackmoor, the view from the Castle Green over three counties of verdant pasture--South, Mid, and Nether Wessex--being as sudden a surprise to the unexpectant traveller's eyes as the medicinal air is to his lungs.
column3: It has a unique position on the summit of a steep and imposing scarp, rising on the north, south, and west sides of the borough out of the deep alluvial Vale of Blackmoor, the view from the Castle Green over three counties of verdant pasture-South, Mid, and Nether Wessex-being as sudden a surprise to the unexpectant traveller's eyes as the medicinal air is to his lungs.

column2: Impossible to a railway, it can best be reached on foot, next best by light vehicles; and it is hardly accessible to these but by a sort of isthmus on the north-east, that connects it with the high chalk table-land on that side.
column3: Impossible to a railway, it can best be reached on foot, next best by light vehicles; and it is hardly accessible to these but by a sort of isthmus on the north-east, that connects it with the high chalk table land on that side.

column2: Such is, and such was, the now world-forgotten Shaston or Palladour. Its situation rendered water the great want of the town; and within living memory, horses, donkeys and men may have been seen toiling up the winding ways to the top of the height, laden with tubs and barrels filled from the wells beneath the mountain, and hawkers retailing their contents at the price of a halfpenny a bucketful.
column3: Such is, and such was, the now world forgotten Shaston or Palladour. column2: This difficulty in the water supply, together with two other odd facts, namely, that the chief graveyard slopes up as steeply as a roof behind the church, and that in former times the town passed through a curious period of corruption, conventual and domestic, gave rise to the saying that Shaston was remarkable for three consolations to man, such as the world afforded not elsewhere.
column3: This difficulty in the water supply, together with two other odd facts, namely, that the chief graveyard slopes up as steeply as a roof behind the church, and that in former times the town passed through a curious period of corruption, conventual and domestic, gave rise to the saying that Shaston was remarkable for three consolations to man, such as the world afforded not elsewhere.

column2: It was a place where the churchyard lay nearer heaven than the church steeple, where beer was more plentiful than water, and where there were more wanton women than honest wives and maids.
column3: It was a place where the churchyard lay nearer heaven than the church steeple, where beer was more plentiful than water, and where there were more wanton women than honest wives and maids.

column2: It is also said that after the Middle Ages the inhabitants were too poor to pay their priests, and hence were compelled to pull down their churches, and refrain altogether from the public worship of God; a necessity which they bemoaned over their cups in the settles of their inns on Sunday afternoons.

column2: It was the resting-place and headquarters of the proprietors of wandering vans, shows, shooting-galleries, and other itinerant concerns, whose business lay largely at fairs and markets.
column3: It was the resting place and headquarters of the proprietors of wandering vans, shows, shooting galleries, and other itinerant concerns, whose business lay largely at fairs and markets.

column2: As strange wild birds are seen assembled on some lofty promontory, meditatively pausing for longer flights, or to return by the course they followed thither, so here, in this cliff-town, stood in stultified silence the yellow and green caravans bearing names not local, as if surprised by a change in the landscape so violent as to hinder their further progress; and here they usually remained all the winter till they turned to seek again their old tracks in the following spring.

column3: I have been thinking, she continued, still in the tone of one brimful of feeling, "that the social moulds civilization fits us into have no more relation to our actual shapes than the conventional shapes of the constellations have to the real star patterns.

column2: I am called Mrs. Richard Phillotson, living a calm wedded life with my counterpart of that name.
column3: I am called mrs Richard Phillotson, living a calm wedded life with my counterpart of that name.

column2: But I am not really Mrs. Richard Phillotson, but a woman tossed about, all alone, with aberrant passions, and unaccountable antipathies...

column2: Now you mustn't wait longer, or you will lose the coach.

column2: Come and see me again.

column2: She stretched out her hand and stroked his forehead pitifully--just once.

column2: Jude said good-bye, and went away into the darkness.

column2: Passing along Bimport Street he thought he heard the wheels of the coach departing, and, truly enough, when he reached the Duke's Arms in the Market Place the coach had gone.
column3: Passing along Bimport Street he thought he heard the wheels of the coach departing, and, truly enough, when he reached the Duke's Arms in the Market Place the coach had gone.

column2: It was impossible for him to get to the station on foot in time for this train, and he settled himself perforce to wait for the next--the last to Melchester that night.
column3: It was impossible for him to get to the station on foot in time for this train, and he settled himself perforce to wait for the next-the last to Melchester that night.

column2: He wandered about awhile, obtained something to eat; and then, having another half-hour on his hands, his feet involuntarily took him through the venerable graveyard of Trinity Church, with its avenues of limes, in the direction of the schools again.
column3: He wandered about awhile, obtained something to eat; and then, having another half hour on his hands, his feet involuntarily took him through the venerable graveyard of Trinity Church, with its avenues of limes, in the direction of the schools again.

column2: They were entirely in darkness.

column2: She had said she lived over the way at Old-Grove Place, a house which he soon discovered from her description of its antiquity.
column3: She had said she lived over the way at Old Grove Place, a house which he soon discovered from her description of its antiquity.

column2: A glimmering candlelight shone from a front window, the shutters being yet unclosed.
column3: A glimmering candlelight shone from a front window, the shutters being yet unclosed.

column2: He could see the interior clearly--the floor sinking a couple of steps below the road without, which had become raised during the centuries since the house was built.
column3: He could see the interior clearly-the floor sinking a couple of steps below the road without, which had become raised during the centuries since the house was built.

column2: Sue, evidently just come in, was standing with her hat on in this front parlour or sitting-room, whose walls were lined with wainscoting of panelled oak reaching from floor to ceiling, the latter being crossed by huge moulded beams only a little way above her head.
column3: Sue, evidently just come in, was standing with her hat on in this front parlour or sitting room, whose walls were lined with wainscoting of panelled oak reaching from floor to ceiling, the latter being crossed by huge moulded beams only a little way above her head.

column2: The mantelpiece was of the same heavy description, carved with Jacobean pilasters and scroll-work.
column3: The mantelpiece was of the same heavy description, carved with Jacobean pilasters and scroll work.

column2: The centuries did, indeed, ponderously overhang a young wife who passed her time here.
column3: The centuries did, indeed, ponderously overhang a young wife who passed her time here.

column2: She had opened a rosewood work-box, and was looking at a photograph. Having contemplated it a little while she pressed it against her bosom, and put it again in its place.
column3: She had opened a rosewood work box, and was looking at a photograph. Having contemplated it a little while she pressed it against her bosom, and put it again in its place.

column2: Then becoming aware that she had not obscured the windows she came forward to do so, candle in hand.
column3: Then becoming aware that she had not obscured the windows she came forward to do so, candle in hand.

column2: It was too dark for her to see Jude without, but he could see her face distinctly, and there was an unmistakable tearfulness about the dark, long-lashed eyes.
column3: It was too dark for her to see jude without, but he could see her face distinctly, and there was an unmistakable tearfulness about the dark, long lashed eyes.

column2: She closed the shutters, and Jude turned away to pursue his solitary journey home.
column3: She closed the shutters, and jude turned away to pursue his solitary journey home.

column2: Whose photograph was she looking at? he said.
column3: Whose photograph was she looking at? he said.

column2: He had once given her his; but she had others, he knew.
column3: He had once given her his; but she had others, he knew.

column2: Yet it was his, surely?
column3: Yet it was his, surely?

column2: He knew he should go to see her again, according to her invitation. Those earnest men he read of, the saints, whom Sue, with gentle irreverence, called his demi-gods, would have shunned such encounters if they doubted their own strength.

column2: He might fast and pray during the whole interval, but the human was more powerful in him than the Divine.
